awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Reconstructing Atmospheric 14C across the Inter Tropical Convergence Zone Using Tropical Tree Rings from South America and Central Africa
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop an observational record of atmospheric radiocarbon (14C) data post-1950 by using calendrically dated tree rings across the intertropical convergence zone (ITCZ). The tree-ring sites are located in South America (Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia, Brazil) and central Africa (Cameroon) across the ITCZ band. These new 14C data will be used to constrain the spatial pattern of atmospheric 14C in the southern hemisphere, which currently relies on samples collected mostly in the eastern part of the southern hemisphere. The researchers will additionally measure the ring width and the stable isotope compositions of Oxygen and Carbon from the tree rings to investigate factors that can cause spatial and temporal variations of 14C variations. These include the seasonality of tree growth and the source of rainwater which reflects atmospheric circulation dynamics. The combined proxies aim to improve: 1) regional and local features of ITCZ circulation and inter-hemispheric exchange; 2) prediction of the ITCZ shifts in response to anthropogenic forcings; 3) the 14C calibration curve for the equatorial southern hemisphere.

The potential Broader Impacts include a better definition of the intra-hemispheric 14C zonal division at lower latitudes, and the 14C timescale in Southern hemisphere which will benefit the paleoclimate community for chronology constraints (accuracy of the radiocarbon method) of the Holocene and climate dynamics of the ITCZ. Results of this project will benefit other fields including: radiocarbon calibration, astrophysics, ecology, biogeochemical and Earth science and archeology. The project will provide training for two undergraduate students and one PhD student. A radiocarbon short course will be organized at University of California Irvine where researchers, students and international collaborators will participate. The data of these project will be integrated in the International intercalibration curve of atmospheric radiocarbon.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Radiocarbon (14C) can be an indicator of changes in the global carbon cycle. Patterns of atmospheric 14CO2 across the planet are driven by natural processes such as atmospheric circulation, and solar and vegetation activity. These patterns are also influenced by human activities such as fossil-fuel combustion. Atmospheric radiocarbon concentrations dramatically shifted in the mid 20th century due to above-ground nuclear bomb explosions that occurred mostly in the northern hemisphere. This amplification of radiocarbon in the atmosphere has made it possible to trace circulation patterns of air parcels and spatiotemporal exchanges of 14C between land or ocean reservoirs and the atmosphere across hemispheric and global scales.

In recent decades, advancements in air-sampling technology have provided high resolution records of 14CO2 variability since the mid 20th century. However, these stations are geographically sparse and short. Growth layers (i.e. rings) in trees make it possible to trace annual and sub-annual atmospheric 14C changes, thereby extending instrumental records several hundreds of years and broadening our understanding of land-atmosphere interactions.

The main goal of this project was to develop new, highly resolved, radiocarbon (14C) records using the wood from annual rings of tropical trees in South America and Central Africa. This work aimed to gain knowledge regarding the geographical particularities and atmospheric circulation patterns affecting the Southern hemisphere 14C concentrations after the 1950s and provide a tree-level perspective of the land-atmosphere carbon cycle in tropical environments.

In this project we performed high-precision 14C measurements (post-1950 A.D.) of sequential tree rings in samples collected from four tree species (Figure 1A) located at lower-latitude sites in regions within the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ; a dynamic moisture boundary associated with a low-pressure belt of trade winds between the Northern and Southern hemispheres). They were developed for northwestern Bolivia, Cameroon, and in Brazil for Central and Eastern Equatorial Amazon. As planned, we performed traditional dendrochronological dating, conducted cellulose extractions, and measured radioisotopes of the tree-ring cellulose.

Key outcomes include the newly developed Keara tree-ring 14C chronology (Figure 1B), as well as results from high-resolution air parcel trajectory models that allowed for distinguishing contributions from air masses of distinct provenance such as the Amazon, the Atlantic and the Pacific Ocean over our study site.

This project is a collaborative effort between scientists at the Tree-Ring Lab of the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University (TRL-LDEO) and the University of California - Irvine. During the duration of this project multiple educational and research opportunities have been provided for researchers and students from the institutions of our South American collaborators.
